So, I'm Ben Brookke. I'm the co-founder

other businesses uh encode privacy rules

I think the biggest challenge for us um
like many founders were finding that
first product market fit. As a founder
in the weeds, you're like so excited
about this thing and you think like
we've got it. This is going to land.
People are going to love it. Nobody

kind of learning to trust the data and
test understand what the customer really

understand your customer. What we ended

what if we just automated this for you?
We'll be like your extended privacy
engineering team. Let us build the

actually a fairly consultative

that was how we approached it. So
especially when it's in I think like a

who knows every nook and cranny of the

sort of like 0 to 10, 10 to 100 and
beyond. There's a few things I'll say
about pricing. The first is make it
super iterative. You really need to
adapt it and change it until you find
your price point. Even then, like it's
only going to last for maybe a year, a
year and a half before you have gotten
enough data to say certain parts of this
are stupid. We need to change it. The
second is you should start as high as
pro possible because most founders are
shocked at the market uh will pay for
their product and especially if you're a
first-time founder you almost feel like
guilty or greedy asking for certain
numbers but ultimately for pricing you
really have to understand the business
value that a company is getting by using
your product. And it kind of sounds like
just corporate jargon, but this is
actually how companies buy. And so if
you're not articulating the actual
dollar value of your product or if you
have no idea how to even start, the
person who's buying your product is
going to try to create that assessment
themselves so that they can take it to
the CFO and get it approved. And so it's
the the real answer is like, do you want
to be involved in that process or do you
not? If it's going to get approved, you
better be involved in that process. So
you actually do have to articulate if
you're going to drive revenue in the
company, how much can you drive? If
you're going to decrease cost, how much
can you decrease cost? Can you actually
articulate what we call value drivers
and educate the person who's trying to
buy your product who's interested in it
and work with them to sort of build this
value case together? And then whatever
that value is, your price should be
about a quarter, two or one/3 of that so
that they get the ROI number on top for
the remaining three quarters.
The real sort of key to our series B was
proving that we could repeatably switch
customers off of the status quo in
privacy, which is incredibly manual
operational work where data owners are
consistently being interviewed, asked to
manually operate on one individual's
data when that individual asks to be
deleted. And that is the status quo sort
of encoded by legacy incumbent software.
The real bet at our series A was like,
can we repeatably show that we can take
market share? Is there a long-term
outcome where transcend takes that sort
of top spot in the market? And so our

And so we we we really tracked like
milestones around like uh our win rate
